fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subobject doctrine of a regular category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal { C } be a regular category, then the subobject doctrine \mathsf { Sub } \colon \mathcal { C } ^ \mathrm {op} \to \mathsf { Lat } has comprehension schema.

Each fiber \mathsf { Sub } (A) has finite limits inherited from \mathcal { C }. By , each f ^{*} has the required left adjoint \exists _{f}. They satisfy the Beck-Chevalley condition because images commute with pullbacks in a regular category. Then by construction the naming functor { \mathopen {}[ \mathord { \hspace {1pt} \text {--} \hspace {1pt}} ] \mathclose {}} _{X} \colon { \mathcal { C } _{/{ X }}} \to \mathsf { Sub } (X) is just \mathsf { Img }, which admits the inclusion functor as a right adjoint.

Let T \colon \mathcal { C } ^ \mathrm {op} \to \mathsf { CAT } be a doctrine. Suppose that for each morphism f \colon X \to Y in \mathcal { C }, f ^{*} admits a left adjoint \Sigma _{f}. Then T is said to satisfy Beck-Chevalley condition if, whenever there is a pullback shown below, we have f ^{*} \Sigma _{g} \cong \Sigma _{h} k ^{*}.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = A, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = B, sw = C, se = D, north = h, south = g, west = k, east = f, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Furthermore, if for each morphism f \colon X \to Y in \mathcal { C }, f ^{*} admits a right adjoint \Pi _{f}. Then this condition implies that f ^{*} \Pi _{g} \cong \Pi _{h} k ^{*} by the uniqueness of adjoint.

Let T \colon \mathcal { C } ^ \mathrm {op} \to \mathsf { Lat } be a doctrine with the structures listed in . Then T has comprehension schema if for each object X \in \mathcal { C } the naming functor { \mathopen {}[ \mathord { \hspace {1pt} \text {--} \hspace {1pt}} ] \mathclose {}} _{X} admits a right adjoint { \mathopen {} \{ X \colon \mathord { \hspace {1pt} \text {--} \hspace {1pt}} \} \mathclose {}}.
Let \mathcal { C } be a category with finite limits and T \colon \mathcal { C } ^ \mathrm {op} \to \mathsf { Lat } be a \mathcal { C }-indexed (pre-)lattice such that

fr:ul.fr:li: For each object X \in \mathcal { C }, the fiber T(X) is cartesian.
For each morphism f \colon X \to Y in \mathcal { C }, f ^{*} admits a left adjoint \Sigma _{f}.
Each left adjoint \Sigma _{f} satisfies the Beck-Chevalley condition.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then we can define a naming functor { \mathopen {}[ \mathord { \hspace {1pt} \text {--} \hspace {1pt}} ] \mathclose {}} _{X} \colon { \mathcal { C } _{/{ X }}} \to T(X) for each object X \in \mathcal { C }. Moreover, for each morphism f \colon X \to Y in \mathcal { C }, the following square commutes up to isomorphism.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = { { \mathcal { C } _{/{ Y }}} }, ne = {T(Y)}, sw = { { \mathcal { C } _{/{ X }}} }, se = {T(X)}, north = { { \mathopen {}[ \mathord { \hspace {1pt} \text {--} \hspace {1pt}} ] \mathclose {}} _{Y}}, south = { { \mathopen {}[ \mathord { \hspace {1pt} \text {--} \hspace {1pt}} ] \mathclose {}} _{X}}, west = { f ^{*} }, east = {T(f)}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For each object f \colon X \to Y in { \mathcal { C } _{/{ Y }}}, take { \mathopen {}[ f ] \mathclose {}} _{Y} := \Sigma _{f}(1). To extend this assignment to a functor, it suffices to show that whenever there is a morphism \alpha \colon f \to g in { \mathcal { C } _{/{ Y }}}, { \mathopen {}[ f ] \mathclose {}} _{Y} \leq { \mathopen {}[ g ] \mathclose {}} _{Y} in T(Y).

To this end, note that \alpha ^{*} (1) \leq \alpha ^{*} g ^{*} { \mathopen {}[ g ] \mathclose {}} _{Y} in T(X) because the unit of the adjunction \Sigma _{g} \dashv g ^{*} gives 1 \leq g ^{*} { \mathopen {}[ g ] \mathclose {}} _{Y}. Since \alpha ^{*}, as a right adjoint, preserves terminal objects and f ^{*} \cong \alpha ^{*} g ^{*} by the (pseudo)functoriality of T, we have 1 \leq f ^{*} { \mathopen {}[ g ] \mathclose {}} _{Y}. Then, the transpose along the adjunction \Sigma _{f} \dashv f ^{*} yields { \mathopen {}[ f ] \mathclose {}} _{Y} \leq { \mathopen {}[ g ] \mathclose {}} _{Y}.
Now for each g \colon Z \to Y, form the following pullback:

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = A, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = X, sw = Z, se = Y, north = { f ^{*} (g)}, south = g, west = k, east = f, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then by Beck-Chevalley, we have
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {aligned} T(f) { \mathopen {}[ g ] \mathclose {}} _{Y} &:= T(f) \Sigma _{g}(1) \\ & \cong \Sigma _{ f ^{*} (g)} k ^{*} (1) && \text {right adjoint preserves terminal object} \\ & \cong \Sigma _{ f ^{*} (g)}(1) \\ &=: { \mathopen {}[ \mathord { \hspace {1pt} \text {--} \hspace {1pt}} ] \mathclose {}} _{X} f ^{*} (g) \end {aligned}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: These isomorphisms assemble into a natural isomorphism f ^{*} { \mathopen {}[ \mathord { \hspace {1pt} \text {--} \hspace {1pt}} ] \mathclose {}} _{Y} \cong { \mathopen {}[ f ^{*} ( \mathord { \hspace {1pt} \text {--} \hspace {1pt}} ) ] \mathclose {}} _{X} since any two parallel morphisms in the preorder T(X) are equal.

A category \mathcal { C } is said to be regular if it is cartesian, has images, and covers are stable under pullback. A functor F \colon \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { D } between regular categories is said to be regular if it is cartesian and preserves covers. Note that since cartesian functors preserve monomorphisms, every regular functor automatically preserves images.

Let F \colon \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { D } be a regular functor and f \colon A \to B be a morphism in \mathcal { C }. By , f admits a cover-mono factorization f = \mathsf { Img } (f) \vartheta _{f}. Then since F preserves monomorphisms and covers, F( \mathsf { Img } (f))F( \vartheta _{f}) forms a cover-mono factorization of F(f). Then by uniqueness, \mathsf { Img } (Ff) \cong F( \mathsf { Img } (f)).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equivalent condition for the existence of images

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal { C } be a category with pullbacks. Then \mathcal { C } has images iff for each morphism f \colon A \to B, the pullback functor f ^{*} \colon \mathsf { Sub } (B) \to \mathsf { Sub } (A) admits a left adjoint \exists _{f} \colon \mathsf { Sub } (A) \to \mathsf { Sub } (B).

By , the pullback functor f ^{*} \colon { \mathcal { C } _{/{ B }}} \to { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} admits \Sigma _{f} \colon { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} \to { \mathcal { C } _{/{ B }}} as a left adjoint.

Let g \colon B' \rightarrowtail B be an arbitrary object in \mathsf { Sub } (B). We need to construct a functor \mathsf { Img } \colon { \mathcal { C } _{/{ B }}} \to \mathsf { Sub } (B) so that each morphism f \to g in { \mathcal { C } _{/{ B }}} corresponds to a unique morphism \mathsf { Img } (f) \to g in \mathsf { Sub } (B).
Let f \to g be an arbitrary morphism in { \mathcal { C } _{/{ B }}}. Then this corresponds to a unique morphism \mathsf {id} _{ A } \to f ^{*} (g) as follows:

This then corresponds to a unique morphism \exists _{f}( \mathsf {id} _{ A } ) \to g under the adjunction \exists _{f} \dashv f ^{*}. Thus, we define \mathsf { Img } by the assignment f \mapsto \exists _{f}( \mathsf {id} _{ A } ). This assignment can be trivially extended to a functor: since the category \mathsf { Sub } (B) is a preorder, every morphism f \to f' in { \mathcal { C } _{/{ B }}} has to be mapped to the unique morphism \mathsf { Img } (f) \to \mathsf { Img } (f') in \mathsf { Sub } (B). This morphism must exist. Indeed, it is the lifting of \mathsf { Img } (f) against \varepsilon _{ \mathsf { Img } (f')} depicted in the following diagram.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \begin {tikzpicture}[diagram] \SpliceDiagramSquare { nw = A', nw/style = pullback, sw = A, ne = B', se = B, north = \varepsilon _{ \mathsf { Img } (f')}, east = \mathsf { Img } (f'), east/style = {>->}, south = \mathsf { Img } (f), south/style = {>->}, } \draw [->,morphism,exists] (sw) to (ne); \end {tikzpicture}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We can now extract the components of the unit and the counit from this correspondence.

html:td.fr:p: Let f \colon A \to B be an object in { \mathcal { C } _{/{ B }}}. The identity morphism \mathsf {id} \colon \mathsf { Img } (f) \to \mathsf { Img } (f) is, by definition, the identity morphism \mathsf {id} \colon \exists _{f}( \mathsf {id} _{ A } ) \to \mathsf { Img } (f), which corresponds to the unit \eta _{ \mathsf {id} _{ A } } \colon \mathsf {id} _{ A } \to f ^{*} ( \mathsf { Img } (f)) of the adjunction \exists _{f} \dashv f ^{*}.

Then since \mathsf { Img } (f) is monic, \eta _{ \mathsf {id} _{ A } } corresponds to a unique morphism \varepsilon _{ \mathsf { Img } (f)} \eta _{ \mathsf {id} _{ A } } \colon f \to \mathsf { Img } (f), where \varepsilon is the counit of the adjunction \Sigma _{f} \dashv f ^{*}. This defines the component of \vartheta at f. This is precisely the lifting of f against \varepsilon _{ \mathsf { Img } (f)}.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \begin {tikzpicture}[diagram] \SpliceDiagramSquare { nw = A', nw/style = pullback, sw = A, ne = B', se = B, north = \varepsilon _{ \mathsf { Img } (f)}, east = \mathsf { Img } (f), east/style = {>->}, south = f, } \draw [->,morphism,exists] (sw) to node[desc] {$ \vartheta _{f}$} (ne); \end {tikzpicture}

html:td.fr:p: Let f \colon A \rightarrowtail B be an object in \mathsf { Sub } (B). Then the identity morphism \mathsf {id} _{f} \colon f \to f corresponds to a unique morphism s \colon \mathsf {id} _{ A } \to f ^{*} (f) by the universal property of pullbacks.
This morphism corresponds to a unique morphism \exists _{f}( \mathsf {id} _{ A } ) \to f under the adjunction \exists _{f} \dashv f ^{*}, which we take as the component of \zeta at f.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If \mathcal { C } has images, then we may define \exists _{f} \colon \mathsf { Sub } (A) \to \mathsf { Sub } (B) as the following composite:
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \mathsf { Sub } (A) \hookrightarrow { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} \xrightarrow { \Sigma _{f} } { \mathcal { C } _{/{ B }}} \xrightarrow { \mathsf { Img } } \mathsf { Sub } (B)
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let i_{A} \colon \mathsf { Sub } (A) \hookrightarrow { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} and i_{B} \colon \mathsf { Sub } (B) \hookrightarrow { \mathcal { C } _{/{ B }}} be the inclusion functors. Note that
Since f ^{*} i_{B} \cong i_{A} f ^{*} by construction, we have

Let \eta and \varepsilon be the unit and counit of this adjunction respectively. Since \mathsf { Sub } (A) is a full subcategory of { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}}, there is a natural isomorphism \iota \colon \mathsf {id} _{ { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} } \stackrel { \sim }{ \smash { \longrightarrow } \rule {0pt}{0.4ex}} i_{A}. Then we can define \eta ' as follows:
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \eta ' := \mathsf {id} _{ { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} } \xrightarrow { \eta } i_{A} f ^{*} \mathsf { Img } \Sigma _{f} \xrightarrow { \iota _{ f ^{*} \mathsf { Img } \Sigma _{f}} } f ^{*} \mathsf { Img } \Sigma _{f} \xrightarrow { f ^{*} \mathsf { Img } \Sigma _{f}( \iota ) } f ^{*} \mathsf { Img } \Sigma _{f}i_{A}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then \eta ' and \varepsilon form the unit and counit of the adjunction \mathsf { Img } \Sigma _{f}i_{A} \dashv f ^{*}.
